DOC.HEAD: Recovery Plan Expected Next Week
DOC.TEXT: The new Panamanian government plans to present economic recovery proposals to the United States next week that will cover damages including looting that occurred when U.S. troops overthrew dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, says the new ambassador to the United States. The new ambassador, Carlos Rodriguez, said Friday night that Panamanian experts working with an inter-agency U.S. team ``have not quantified anything, and we are not demanding anything.'' Asked about reports that war damage would amount to $3 billion to $10 billion, he replied, ``It is not possible to quantify matters with that degree of precision.'' The economic recovery proposal ``was designed, prior to the military action, to restore Panama's economy, but it has been updated to reflect the military action,'' Rodriguez said in an interview. ``There were damages, including the Chorillo area, and merchants who suffered looting from the interruption in police services,'' he said. Reports from Panama say supporters of Noriega set fire to the Chorillo area, inhabited by many poor people near his old headquarters. Some 13,000 people took shelter in a nearby athletic complex. The Chamber of Commerce in Panama City has estimated damages from looting alone in that city at $2 billion. A team of U.S. experts already has gone to Panama and hopes to ``make a presentation to the press on Tuesday of the same proposals'' being put forward to the United States government, Rodriguez said. U.S. sanctions against the Noriega regime over the past two years have caused that nation's economy to shrink by an estimated 10 percent to 15 percent annually, some analysts have said. Some estimates put unemployment above 20 percent, and the country of around 2\ million people has a foreign debt estimated at $5.6 billion. Cash totaling $50 million was flown into Panama on Friday from the United States, part of frozen assets now released. Panama has no national currency of its own and uses U.S. dollars for all its transactions.
